comments.commentBody: Aren't American elections decided by less than 4%?
@Paul: OK then. At least you are very clear on this: you do not believe in democracy, but instead a benevolent (?) dictatorship. run by a liberal elite who "know what is best for everyone".
Americans tend to diminish and disrespect what they fear.  The thought that this might be a precursor for a Trump win is a difficult one.

I think what the NYT is reporting is the upheaval within the UK itself. If everyone in the UK was saying, "great! Brexit won!" and the economy was solid, then that would be the news. Instead, the pound is falling, both Conservatives and Labour have leadership crises and Leave advocates are walking  back promises. About the only person who seems to be providing clear-sighted leadership at the moment is Nicola Sturgeon -- and she is advocating breaking up the UK. This is not the New York Times passing judgment, it is the NYT reporting on the UK passing judgment on itself.
This is not going to destroy the UK. Why is everyone addicted to panic?

Is there any reader so naive as to believe that the British people had no good reasons for wanting  to leave--that they just held this vote on a lark? Next, who are the Americans so arrogant as to pontificate that the British cannot manage themselves successfully as a nation?   NYT, your proselytizing for special interests' contempt for a citizens vote and your efforts to spread fear on the behalf of business are a disgrace.

and ElkE ,

Unlike the British spelling, the ONE-L spelling of JEWELER and DEVILED EGG did indeed beDEVIL me initially.
On the other hand, SPUDS are grown by New Brunswickers ; but it is their neighbouring province, Prince Edward (not HANS ) Island, that is known as SPUDS Island.
While my first and last names have an E in each syllable, they are not French . This YENTA won't --TWEET them here.
LITTERBUGS made me think of Jitterbugs and the Lindy, which I SEE on the TELEvision is making a comeback.
If you look carefully, you can see Tyrell and Martell ships on Dany's flotilla.  It Seems if Targaryen has already parlayed with them.
Speaking of Arya: did I mishear, or did Jon Snow get the credit for killing Walter Frey?
I thought the music was too obtrusive, too modern-sounding, and distracting.

1) I literally had to take a walk around the block after this episode, shouting at the top of my lungs "R+L=J!", A girl needed whiskey upon her return.
2) Was it just me, or did the music in this episode surpass itself?
3) Wow, Arya and Varys travel fast.

Fabulous episode! Beautifully filmed, amazingly acted and truly exciting. TV at its best! The quick dissolve from baby Jon's face to his current state was revealing and the final scene with the ships and dragons crossing the sea was poetic. Great stuff!
Have Face Will Travel. Wire Arya.

comments.userLocation: Somewhere on the Appalachian Trail, with days off to watch Game of Thrones
comments.commentBody:
I disagree. There will be a great emotional conflict between Cersei and Jamie now that she has taken her revenge,

Disappointed that Sansa wasn't annointed Queen of the North.

Well, no more questions.

In a way it's sad to know so many answers that we've been waiting for. Has the mystery left the show altogether? There are so few questions from the past now. Even Jon Snow's parentage is, at least mostly, apparent. It just seems that we now have an action oriented, strategic and tactical seasons comping up. Not so much the yearning of the unknowns.

Thank you for this work. You are applying to medical school and I am ending my medical career. My wife died March 23, 2015 under similar circumstances although thankfully days not months. My wife made it clear to me during our 30 years relationship that she
Never wanted advanced life support. She had advanced cancer and a complex surgical procedure which failed and as sepsis set in her liver, kidneys and lungs failed. All the doctors said we can save her except the liver specialist. He said if she lives she will need a liver transplant but you must be cancer free for two years before you get on the list. He then described the horror of her future life waiting on a liver. I proceeded with terminating her life support knowing I was respecting her wishes and doing the right thing. As I went through the grief process and missed her so much I became convinced I made a mistake because all the others said they could save her. They never said at what cost, only the liver expert told the truth. Thank you for bringing this work forward, it has reminded me of why I made my decision and why it was the right decision. I will never be at peace with the transition of my wife but I can be at peace with the decisions I made about her end of life care. Thank you so much

Define "know". It appears a wide range of people, some of whom should open their minds and look more carefully, are repeating the Republican opposition work on the Clintons.

That's not knowledge, it's prejudice. And it is tired old stuff, inaccurate and lame.

National economic objectives are all but lost on both continents. The status quo is the political agenda of a fictitious alliance of "Globalists". Deflation is merely the price of maintenance. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five_Star_Movement

The Scottish National Party will take any pretext for threatening to hold an independence referendum. If it weren't Brexit, it would be something else down the road.

As for the border between Eire and Northern Ireland having to be closed, I doubt that will happen - most likely the UK immigration border will move to the ports and airports of Northern Ireland.
No they don't. Media manipulation of the facts.

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
It is not the destruction of a country, Chicken Little. Sheesh!
If the Scots break away they would be free to rejoin the E.U., and my word from them is that they loved being part of the E.U.

Of course, this highlights the problem that like all bureaucracies, the E.U. is effective in helping slow, disorganized economies begin to progress but stinks at helping large economies actually grow.

The UK is supposed to be a Parliamentary democracy, which implies that the will of Parliament should take precedence over a referendum. After all, Cameron only called for it for party political reasons to satisfy anti-EU members of his party, never dreaming it would backfire.

In the current House of Commons, a clear majority of the members is in favor of remaining in the EU, and if they were to summon the spine they could make it impossible for the next Prime Minister to proceed with Brexit, unless he/she called for an election which resulted in a Leave majority. Already many voters appear to regret their Leave vote

The tennis season lasts from January to November. That's why a calendar-year Grand Slam is special, and in fact the true Grand Slam. It is achieved during one tennis season.

Only Laver has won it TWICE. No other man or woman have been able to achieve that.

Graf has won a true Grand Slam in 1988. Serena would have to win all four Slams next year to match that. I strongly doubt that at her age she can do such a thing. She's barely playing and has won only one tournament, not a Slam, since she was outplayed by Vinci at last year's US Open.

All props to Serena, but I have enjoyed the runs by Pennetta, Kerber, and Muguruza in the last 3 slams. Pennetta was "light as a feather"and deadly accurate, Kerber found the craziest angles and her serve became a weapon, and Muguruza was, as Judy Murray quipped, "muguruthless" in her aggressive game and massive strokes (not to mention a funky match point lob) in Paris. I wish the fans, including the "Serena is Queen" crowd, could just let the action play out match after match and appreciate the results and the wonderful, individual sport tennis is. Personally, I am hoping for a Keys or Radwanska breakthrough, just to add another new big name to the mix.
Rafa is a 1st class mental case. Can't bear to watch him play. Watching Serena, I am reminded of Mike Tyson.
Wow, such a positive attitude toward others.  I wonder who or what you remind people of.

I don't know what it is, but I don't particularly have much affection for Nole. I definitely have affection for Rafa, Fed, Murray, Wawrinka, Nishikori. I have been watching tennis since the 70's and even have affection for McEnroe, definitely Borg. Probably the most for Rafa because of his dogged determination to come back from injury. I definitely am in awe of what Djokovic can do. I am amazed by his range and flexibility, his ability to go from defense to offense in a nanosecond. So if he wins a grand slam, I will accept it, but not celebrate long. I don't know if what I am saying is just about me, or if the sentiments are more widely shared.

I like Serena and wish her well, but somehow I am more drawn to Venus and her story of comeback. It's funny how these things are.

Serena Williams is #1 among women only on paper. Yes just like those peskie valedictorians who are valedictorians only on paper because they have the greatest Grade Point Average.

On the other hand the definition of a true valedictorian is the a student, who scored the Greatest Point Average and recognized as the true #1 in tennis is also based on greatest points accumulated. Tournaments are graded based on a computer evaluation of the standard of participants competing in the previous year's tournament. Points are awarded for singles,doubles and mixed doubles play.

The idea of numbers determining outcomes is indeed not recognized by everyone. President Obama is said to be president in 2008 just because 69,498,516 people voted for him which was about 10,000,000 more than those who voted for McCain and president in 2012 just because 65,915,79 voted for Obama which was close to 6,000,000 those voting for Romney. Yet some fools like Trump still do not get it that the number of votes is the reason that Obama is our president.

The way of electing presidents is based on the US Constitution while the way of recognizing true number one in tennis is based on rules established by the Association of Tennis Professionals' (ATP) merit-based method for determining rankings in tennis.

...jerk?  ...only on paper? OK. Everyone has a right to an opinion. But, you are missing two of the most exceptional athletes to ever walk this planet. And, they are competing now. Sorry you're missing it.

"Nadal was for the most part a one slam wonder"

Make that a 14-Slam wonder !
Also Rafa is the only player ever to have won 3 consecutive Slams on 3 different surfaces. Djoker, who does not have a tenth of Rafa's talent, has a lot more to achieve to match Rafa's record.

Not a domestic violence case. Misdemeanor obstruction plea. Co-accused acquitted.

Nuff said?

Of course he deserves another opportunity.

No need to make it any more complicated than that.

I watched Reyes entire career with the Mets, and I'm not a fan. He played hard only when he felt like it, which, IMO, wasn't nearly often enough. One need only look at his BA for his walk year vs the rest of his career for proof.
It's easy to see why the cheapskate Wilpons are giving him a chance, but, hopefully, he either plays his heart out in appreciation for this second chance, or he's gone.

As a baseball decision, this is a low risk maneuver. The true risk was always the reaction from the portion of fans (and every group has some) who do not wish to acknowledge that mistakes are a part of life and consequences must be faced. The MLB policy regarding domestic violence is in its infancy. The penalty is applied according to the judgement of the Baseball Commissioner. Justice, in that regard has been served. For all of you so-called Mets fans choosing to turn your backs on the team for this decision, it shows you to be small. Very small.

When their so-called champions hide behind phrases like "establishment journalists" and "corrupted elite circles," rather than clearly setting forth clarifying facts, it leads to "the people" making stupid decisions. The Germans in the thirties reacted to real miseries. However, because they were ignorant, they voted in Hitler.   Because this led to mass murder, it is hard to sympathize with those German voters.  Plight or no plight.  In my book, your use of the terms "establishment journalists" and "corrupted elite" indicates that you are, intentionally or not, corrupting discourse and discouraging "the people" from any kind of thoughtful response.

Great link - more from same:

"Media reaction to the Brexit vote falls into two general categories: (1) earnest, candid attempts to understand what motivated voters to make this choice, even if that means indicting one’s own establishment circles, and (2) petulant, self-serving, simple-minded attacks on disobedient pro-leave voters for being primitive, xenophobic bigots (and stupid to boot), all to evade any reckoning with their own responsibility. "

The NYT seems to be almost exclusively in (2) except for Dr. Krugman - somewhat.

Susan,

Re: "rather than clearly setting forth clarifying facts, it leads to "the people" making stupid decisions. The Germans in the thirties reacted to real miseries."

You are missing the point: It is the job of the (supposedly adversarial) press to set forth clarifying tasks. Our lapdog press refuses to clarify these facts, because it is inconvenient to the status quo holders of power. The fact that they refuse to do so, is making them irrelevant now, and if they recant later and genuinely wish to avoid a demagogue - too late. Their credibility is gone - sacrificed in exchange for access to powerful people, advertisers, money, prestige, etc.

Specifics?

Go to Dean Baker's blog for some examples of how our economic reporting is full of "errors" used to justify policies that benefit the powerful:

http://cepr.net/blogs/beat-the-press/

The failure of the press to do their job challenging authority is putting us all at risk. We are closer than you think to electing Trump. Ignoring the economic needs of 50 million people earning less than $15 per hour, and shaming / insulting them, isn't a smart long term strategy.

Some great excerpts from Glenn Greenwald have been posted - here is another:

"There are many factors explaining why establishment journalists now have almost no ability to stem the tide of anti-establishment rage, even when it’s irrational and driven by ignoble impulses. Part of it is that the internet and social media have rendered them irrelevant, unnecessary to disseminate ideas. Part of it is that — due to their distance from them — they have nothing to say to people who are suffering and angry about it other than to scorn them as hateful losers. Part of it is that journalists — like anyone else — tend to react with bitterness and rage, not self-assessment, as they lose influence and stature."

"But a major factor is that many people recognize that establishment journalists are an integral part of the very institutions and corrupted elite circles that are authors of their plight. Rather than being people who mediate or inform these political conflicts, journalists are agents of the forces that are oppressing them. And when journalists react to their anger and suffering by telling them that it’s invalid and merely the byproduct of their stupidity and primitive resentments, that only reinforces the perception that journalists are their enemy, thus rendering journalistic opinion increasingly irrelevant."

https://theintercept.com/2016/06/25/brexit-is-only-the-latest-proof-of-t...

I am so tired of hearing Republican opposition work on Hillary coming from people who claim to be Democrats and/or progressives. Why to do repeat these oversimplified memes. Why do you buy the hate?

Brexit should have shown us all that burning down the house just leaves people homelsss. It will be the little people who pay.

It's the Narrow Sea, but take a look at the map: Slavers' Bay is pretty far away from the Narrow Sea, and you have to get around the smouldering ruins of Valyria (which is a fearsome place in the books, not so much in the show). It's not just a crossing like the Channel...more like sailing from Istanbul, through the Straights of Gibraltar, on your way to the Azores.
They float.
I think they are probably hugging the coast, right?

Cersei is the Mad Queen.

One question that worries me. Where is the aircraft carrier, or whatever it would take, where the dragons can alight and take a breather? Can they fly nonstop to Westeros without a rest?
